Course Section Definition Public Notes:
Study the 5th most spoken language in the world! This is an interactive introduction to Portuguese language. The rich cultures of Brazil and Portugal are incorporated in all the materials used in class, providing students with an opportunity to immerse in authentic sociocultural situations.  
See the full course overview: https://fhis.ubc.ca/course-description/PORT101/    

Contact us here: https://fhis.ubc.ca/undergraduate-advising-contact-form/

Course Section: PSYC_V 101-001 - Introduction to Biological and Cognitive Psychology
PSYC_V 101-003 - Introduction to Biological and Cognitive Psychology
Course Section Definition Public Notes:
This course is part of the Coordinated Arts Program, Individual & Society stream,   
https://cap.arts.ubc.ca/streams/individual-society/. Students must register in both Term  
1 and Term 2 courses in CAP. 
 
This course is clustered with SOCI_V 102-CAP, and the Individual & Society sections of the CAP stream seminar CAP_V 100. For SOCI_V 102-CAP, please register in both the lecture, and one of the following discussion sections: SOCI_V 102-C1A, SOCI_V 102-C1B, SOCI_V 102-C1C, or SOCI_V 102-C1D. PSYC_V 101-003, and CAP_V 100 do not have any additional discussion sections. Follow the prompts to register in all stream seminars (1), lectures (2), and tutorials (1-2) each term. 

For step-by-step instructions, please visit: https://cap.arts.ubc.ca/program/registration/ 
 
If you encounter any issues with registration into CAP, please contact us at support.fyip@ubc.ca
Clustered Course Sections: PSYC_V 101-003 - Introduction to Biological and Cognitive Psychology

Course Section Definition Public Notes:
Delivery Mode -This is a hybrid course. Students are expected to meet in-person on the days and times listed. In addition, course content will be delivered asynchronously.  ​

Waitlist Policy -All waitlists will follow a first come, first serve policy, unless specified otherwise. Once a course is full, its status will be changed to “Waitlist” and students who register will be automatically added to the waitlist.

Course Section: RGST_V 160-101 - Introduction to Religions: Judaism, Christianity, Islam
Course Section Definition Public Notes:
Jewish, Christian, and Muslim Religious Traditions. Visit amne.ubc.ca for full course descriptions.

Cross-listed with RGST 160 001.

** This course has TWO required sections: a lecture and a discussion. This lecture section only meets MW. Please email amne.undergrad@ubc.ca with your ranked preference for Friday’s discussion section. You will be assigned to a discussion section depending on your enrolment time and seat availability.**

The discussion sections are: 
AMNE 160 L1A:  F 9-10 am
AMNE 160 L1B:   F 10-11 am
AMNE 160 L1C:  F 11-12 pm

If the course is full or blocked, or if you do not meet restrictions for the available seats, please register for the waitlist. Students will be moved manually from the waitlist into the course section. If the course is blocked by showing available seats, this is normal and means that waitlist transfer have not yet taken place. Email amne.undergrad@ubc.ca with any questions.

Explore how fashion helps forge individual, brand, national, and other cultural identities by examining the national history of Italian fashion since the post-WWII period and its global dimensions.  
ITAL 110 and RMST 100 are taught in the same classroom at the same time by the same instructor. All students must register in RMST 100.

See the full course overview: https://fhis.ubc.ca/course-description/RMST100   

Language of Instruction: English 

Contact us here: https://fhis.ubc.ca/undergraduate-advising-contact-form/ 

2 seats for this section have been saved from open registration to support students who missed registration due to WD technical issues. Please reach out to fhis.undergrad@ubc.ca if you need support on this.

Students are taught Russian in a vibrant and energizing way, where linguistic practices and vocabulary-learning are intertwined with an appreciation of the broader Slavic world and the culture of Russophone people, in and beyond Russia.

Sample syllabus here.
